title: What not getting an S really means.
body:
So we have all had that moment when we do really well in a game chasing that token or that chest, the game ends, and for some reason you just don't get the S.

We always see that as the problem _"I didn't get my S"_, but we are so focused on that, that we aren't seeing the true issue.
The scores are given based on how your score compares to the average score of that champion, so to get an S you have to be _above_ the average score.

The above image is a game where my friend was playing Garen. 
Now he was doing pretty well, 9/1/2 is no score to scoff at, thats basically half kill participation _(pretty damn good for a "Tank")_, and his farm wasn't shabby at all for 20 minutes.

My friend did not get an S, nor did he get an S-, in fact he didn't even get an A+, his score landed him a simple A.
Now thats unfair that you can play well and not be rewarded with at least an S-, but the issue here isn't that he didn't get an S.

The issue is: that 9/1/2 with 121 CS at 20 minutes, is the _expected average score_ for a Garen at 20 minutes.

Remember that this guy is the bog-standard-piss-easy beginner champ who is designed purely to give new players a champion that is accessible to their skill level. He shouldn't be expected to _(as a tank let us not forget)_ be 9/1 at 20 minutes.

That shouldn't be the average score of any champion.

replies.body: I've always grown up learning that C is average. Even if you scaled it up to B being average (since you are adding an S Tier), A is still not average, but quite a bit above average. S, though, would be amazing compared to the average.

I think in most areas, C is the lowest possible score that constitutes a 'pass', 
it's not an average.

C usually means 50%, which is only half the total score. 
So for that to be an average, it'd mean that half of the population would be having to be completely failing to play Garen in any capacity. Which seems unlikely.

Its more likely that B is the absolute average score, but even then if A is only slightly above average (with 9/1) that means that his B score is still an incredibly good score.

The scores are graded on a bell curve to the best of my knowledge. The bell curve means that instead of it being "get above x score to get an S" it's, "be in the top x% to get an S". 2% was thrown around a while ago but I can't speak to it'as accuracy, nor if that 2% was supposedly for all S grades or only S+.

For reference this is what a bell curve looks like:
http://i.imgur.com/QXH5ro2.jpg

If we assume B is the 0 standard deviation (aka the average) then that means B is always going to be the most common score, since there is always a fixed percentage of Bs, As, etc. So to get any given grade you have to be in the top or bottom % defined by Riot (ofc we don't know what those percentages are). If we assume A covers the top....let's say 20%, and S- is the top 10% then that means your friendos score landed between the top 10 and 20%, which is still well above the average.

In a bell curve like this the average will always be 50% since it's a median average, we just don't know what grade lands where on the curve.

If anyone lives in Queensland they ought to know all about bell curves since it's how the OP (school grading) system works (which btw is the dumbest thing ever).

Yea I understand that system, I'm pretty sure thats how they would grade it too.
_(and yea its a dumb system, it screws people over if you happen to get a class full of intelligent people)_

But it doesn't change the fact that Garen is getting wicked good scores and they aren't counting for much.

I 100% guarantee you that you get 9/1/2 with farm like that on Azir at 20 mins, and thats an S+ in the bag. 
And thats coming from a champ who is supposed to get kills _(Garen is not exactly supposed to be a DPS kills champ remember)_

Yeah but Garen can also be one of those snowbally tanks that gets too tanky to kill and too damagey to escape, which unfortunately means that his high scores are really high, while his low scores probably aren't all that low (being low skill cap). That being the case all the just good scores are pushed way down in ranks, and only the truly phenomenal scores will get the coveted S+ ranks.

It sucks sometimes, but I see the logic in using a bell curve. It rewards the best of the best (without discriminating by bronze-challenger rank) and makes it difficult for just casual players of a champion to get random S+ ranks. They mean more this way.

Not sure where you are getting this from.

F - Fail
E - 51-60%
D - 61-70%
C - 71-80%
B - 81-90%
A - 91-100%

C isn't nearly as bad as just passing in most places, this is the grading system.

> Not sure where you are getting this from.

4 years of having to work the university system.
Some courses you couldn't even get into without getting A's, 
so D's and E's were most certainly out of the question.

"C's get degrees" is the saying.

Not "E's get degrees"... because they don't, because E is a fail, at least at that level.
Goddamn, those are my marking guidelines at high school
At my University, C is 55% (C- is 50%), with A+ being 90% and D- being 35% (and E is <35%).

Not shown:
Wards - placement and removal; I've found basic warding and counter warding will almost guarantee an S so long as I'm playing half decently. 
Gold and backing timing - is another big issue in the formula; if he hung in lane until he could outright his boots and an item, he lost his S right there.
Damage done and taken - also known as fight participation; participating in kills is great, but if you're always late to the fight you're not much good.

Also, 121 CS is actually trash at nearly 23 minutes; bear in mind an S is meant to be an amazing game, CS wise I'd say only Vayne was even in the running. Also, tanks are generally rewarded more for assists than kills (from what I've seen - I don't have the actual formula) so he may have gained less towards an S than if he went 2/1/9.

I'd also point out that, as others have said, A is above average - probably in around the 80th percentile, if not slightly higher. I would say that he did perform around an A, based on the score and your praise - I assume he had a great game, he's probably done better, but it was great. He did not perform (according to stats) like he was an amazing Garen who completely outclassed his opponent, and did massive amounts for his team (he'd have both more CS and assists if he did). None of this is to detract from him, I'm simply stating.

I do agree with the underlying argument you're making here though, if I understand correctly, just not with your specifics. 
I think that we (well, riot) need to be watching where their system places the S benchmark, especially as it's tied to the loot crates. Players want a rewarding experience, more over we want a continually rewarding experience. I shouldn't be getting an S every other game (like I used to when the system was new), but likewise, I should be able to get at least one a week (I consider myself a "barely silver" player, though my ranking is normally mid - high silver; to put this in perspective) - especially on champions that I 'main'. To this ends, I think the system should also account for skill of the player; maybe half half, if my game is 3* better than my normal, but only an A - A+ by the entire player base average, I should get an S- - S in my humble opinion; and I think this would rectify your issue as well, as your friend would then have likely scored ~S-.

Long post, but I hope that A) I helped you understand the system a little more (it's terribly documented, like everything LoL related) and B) put some valid thought-food into the general mix. 

Peace!

these are just roughly as I have gone 200 cs in 20 minutes
I have the same thing with vayne I went 35/6/9 in a normal game 300 cs in 50 mins and I got a a- and I was like wtf

It's actually pretty hard to get an S in one-sided games because you sacrifice cs to close out the game with your team, you usually get a low KP because someone on the other side of the map (who is probably gonna get an S) is 10/0, smashed down a tower or two and got priority access to farm when you all grouped because 'they're carrying'.

I've never had a problem with the scoring system because for some weird reason unless I actually feed I always get anywhere between an A and an S+ on ANY champion that I play. Which has lead me to believe I'm a pretty good player, at least for my elo.

Elo has nothing to do with the grading system.

It actually does - just not in the way that it's [kills-deaths*ELO] or anything bland like that. Think of it like this, if you're versing someone with half your skill (and thus theoretically, ELO) - are you going to do as well as you usually do, are you going to suffer, or are you going to capitalise on every little mistake that they make?

Being good at ones current ELO means that they're capable of out playing their opponents, thus making the most of what's presented (otherwise only challengers would ever get an S)!
I never said elo had anything to do with it, I just said because I always perform well I'm pretty good for a silver player {{sticker:zombie-brand-facepalm}}

Do you think part of the problem is that it's Garen and people underestimate him. He does good damage early and gets super tanky later on. It might be that he has less worse scores than feast or famine champs.
